memo:
BILL NUMBER:S1712

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the judiciary law, in relation to nonpartisan quadrennial
review of the adequacy of judgeships of the unified court system

PURPOSE:
Directs the Office of Court Administration to issue a report every
four years regarding the adequacy and allocation of judgeships in and
among the state-paid trial courts of the state.

SUMMARY:
Amends Judiciary Law section 212 to require the Office of Court
Administration to transmit to the Legislature and Governor, every four
years starting November 1 after enactment, a report on the adequacy
and allocation of judgeships among the nine state-paid trial courts.
Such reports and their recommendations must be without regard to
partisanship but based on the administration of justice in and among
the courts and broader justice system, taking into consideration
current and projected dockets. Reports would include the objective
basis for any recommendations.

JUSTIFICATION:
Current law provides no mechanism by which the legislative and
executive branches can receive, on a predictable basis, objective
assessments of the adequacy and allocation of judgeships in
state-paid courts relative to dockets and other incidents of the
administration of justice. This gap in the law governing the Judiciary
impairs the effective operation of the courts and frustrates efforts
to redress calendar congestion that delays proceedings and directly
impacts litigants and their families and communities.

Dockets among New York's state-paid courts are nearing five million
new tilings annually, dwarfing all federal courts combined and most
other state judiciaries. Explosive growth in New York dockets,
combined with new procedures for many case types, impose mounting
burdens on many courts, litigants and allied justice agencies
statewide. The limited issue this bill seeks to address is how to
measure the judgeship needs, if any, arising from these trends.

On its own initiative over the last several decades, the Judiciary
established an informal periodic process to propose adjustments in
and among City Courts outside New York City. This process has worked
to the benefit of the institutional Judiciary, the legislative and
executive branches, the affected courts and the regions they serve -
by providing a regular timetable and basis for this inquiry. Under
this system, the Legislature receives a periodic assessment, based on
dockets and projections in each of the 62 City Courts, as well as
qualitative reports on emerging trends. Using these data and the
timetable's regularity, OCA makes a comprehensive proposal to the

Legislature, which then has full discretion to consider and adjust
This process has streamlined what once was a haphazard approach that
left some City Courts and their communities without needed resources
and others with extra capacity. With benefit of this process, City
Courts have evolved commensurate with their duties, with system-wide
efficiencies and justice benefits for affected cities, counties and
their civil and criminal justice systems. Likewise, the Legislature -
while always free to make mid-cycle adjustments - has streamlined a
process that otherwise would
invite stand alone bills for each of 62 separate courts.

By contrast, for the other eight state-paid trial courts - Supreme
Court, Family Court, County Court, Surrogate's Court, Court of
Claims, New York City Civil Court, New York City Criminal Court, and
District Courts on Long Island - there is no periodic process to
measure judgeship needs and propose adjustments. Adjustments in these
courts generally remain haphazard in and among the 62 counties of the
state, and some courts have grown critically backlogged. For
instance, Family Court has not had a judgeship package focused on
that essential tribunal's needs since the court's creation in 1962.
As of the date this bill first was proposed, there wasn't a single
new Family Court judgeship created in New York City for over 20
years, even though dockets and the burdens of Family Court
adjudications have ballooned. Dockets in other courts and venues also
have become critically high relative to judgeships.

This bill's purpose is to provide for other state-paid courts the
regular, streamlined and objective process on which the Legislature
has come to rely for City Courts. This bill would provide the
first-ever snapshot of potential judgeship needs for all state-paid
courts, as a system, relative to dockets and the administration of
justice. As demonstrated above, history shows that absent such a
systematic approach, the public and their representatives cannot have
full confidence that the administration of justice properly is served
in and among the courts of this state.

Accordingly, this measure would amend Judiciary Law section 212 to
direct the Office of Court Administration to transmit a quadrennial
report on the sufficiency of judgeships in and among the state-paid
courts, based on current and projected dockets and other
administration-of-justice factors. The amendment would require that
such reports be entirely without regard to partisanship and based on
objective data, which would be submitted as part of the report to
inform the discretion of the Legislature and governor.

Nothing in this bill would intrude on the constitutional prerogatives
of the legislative and executive branches, which would retain their
discretion in relation to judgeships consistent with Article VI of
the Constitution. This bill would, however, create a first-ever
process for the legislative and executive branches to examine the
judgeship needs of the system as a system, to promote efficiency and
targeted response to docket trends. The result would be a tailored

approach that allows regular improvements for the benefit of
litigants, their families and communities, civil and criminal justice
agencies, and the cause of justice itself.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS FOR STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS:
None.
